verses.text: Incline your ear, O LORD, and answer me, for I am poor and needy.
verses.comment: The psalmist begins with a humble request, recognizing his dependence on the LORD. This posture of humility is foundational in spiritual life, reminding believers of the importance of seeking the Lord in prayer (see James 4:6).

verses.text: Guard my soul, for I am devoted to you; save your servant who trusts in you; you are my God.
verses.comment: Devotion and trust are marks of true service to God. The psalmist affirms his commitment, echoing the call to a life of dedication and continual trust (see Matthew 6:24).

verses.text: Be gracious to me, O Lord, for to you do I cry all the day.
verses.comment: Appealing to God's grace reinforces both human need and God's readiness to respond compassionately, alluding to themes developed fully in the New Testament (see Hebrews 4:16).

verses.text: Gladden the soul of your servant, for to you, O Lord, I lift up my soul.
verses.comment: To lift one's soul to God is an image of surrender and deep longing for God's presence and joy—a posture central to spiritual devotion and worship.

verses.text: For you, Lord, are good, and ready to forgive, and abundant in mercy to all who call upon you.
verses.comment: God's readiness to forgive reveals His goodness and mercy. This anticipates the rich outpouring of grace in the new covenant and the sacramental forgiveness of sins (see 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: Listen, O LORD, to my prayer; give ear to the voice of my pleas for mercy.
verses.comment: Persistent prayer and confidence in God's attentiveness are central themes; the faithful are always encouraged to approach God in prayer (see Philippians 4:6).

verses.text: In the day of my trouble I call upon you, for you will answer me.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s confidence in God's response echoes the New Testament promise that all who call on the Lord will be saved (see Romans 10:13).

verses.text: There is none like you among the gods, O Lord, nor are there any works like yours.
verses.comment: The uniqueness and supremacy of God over all spiritual beings is affirmed. This exclusivity is fulfilled in Christ who reveals the fullness of God to humanity (see John 14:9).

verses.text: All the nations you have made shall come and worship before you, O Lord, and shall glorify your name.
verses.comment: The universal call to worship prefigures the inclusion of the Gentiles and the global community united in worship (see Revelation 7:9).

verses.text: For you are great and do wondrous things; you alone are God.
verses.comment: God’s wondrous deeds invite awe and deepen faith. Such testimonies feed the faith of the whole community, not just individuals.

verses.text: Teach me your way, O LORD, that I may walk in your truth; unite my heart to fear your name.
verses.comment: The psalmist asks not just for knowledge, but for transformation—a heart undivided in devotion. Christian tradition sees the moral law written on believers’ hearts (see Jeremiah 31:33).

verses.text: I will give thanks to you, O Lord my God, with all my heart, and will glorify your name forever.
verses.comment: Thanksgiving is a continual sacrifice and a priority in worship, aligning with the repeated call to praise God in all circumstances (see 1 Thessalonians 5:18).

verses.text: For great is your steadfast love toward me; you have delivered my soul from the depths of Sheol.
verses.comment: God's faithful love and salvation even from Sheol points to hope in life after death. God's redemptive work for His people anticipates resurrection hope (see Matthew 12:40; 1 Peter 3:19).

verses.text: O God, arrogant men have risen against me; a band of violent men seeks my life, and they have not set you before them.
verses.comment: Opposition from the wicked is a recurring theme. The psalmist’s suffering prefigures Christ’s own passion, offering a model for patient endurance.

verses.text: But you, O Lord, are a God merciful and gracious, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness.
verses.comment: This verse repeats one of the earliest and most enduring confessions about God’s character. God’s faithfulness and mercy are central to the message of salvation history.

verses.text: Turn to me and be gracious; give your strength to your servant, and save the son of your handmaid.
verses.comment: ‘Son of your handmaid’ denotes profound humility and service to God’s will—a title echoed in Mary’s humility (see Luke 1:38), but also applied broadly to all who serve God with devotion.

verses.text: Show me a sign of your favor, that those who hate me may see and be put to shame because you, LORD, have helped me and comforted me.
verses.comment: The request for a sign is not for selfish proof but for vindication of the faithful. In the New Testament, the gift of signs is completed in the coming of the Messiah, who manifests God's ultimate faithfulness (see Matthew 12:38-40).
